text: When I was younger and I was starting off, I used to think it's all about the product. If you've got a really cool product to work on, your growth's guaranteed. And if you got really a product which no one cares about or a stream which no one cares about, then your growth is going to be slightly slower. But as I started seeing more and more product managers at their craft, I saw that working on a cool product area is not the only thing.
speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
context: Lenny asks Vikrama about the common traits of product managers who have had rapid career growth. Vikrama explains how his understanding of career success evolved from his early career misconception. He initially believed that working on exciting, high-impact products would automatically guarantee career advancement, while working on less visible products would slow growth. However, through observing many product managers over his decade and a half of experience, he discovered this assumption was flawed.
vocabulary_highlights: stream which no one cares about
text_ko: 젊었을 때, 커리어 초반엔 모든 게 프로덕트(product) 문제라고 생각했어요. 진짜 멋진 프로덕트를 다루고 있으면 성장(growth)은 보장된다고 믿었죠. 반대로 아무도 관심 없는 제품이나 사업 분야라면 성장 속도가 더딜 거라고도 생각했고요. 그런데 여러 훌륭한 프로덕트 매니저(product manager)들을 직접 보면서, 멋진 제품 분야에서 일하는 것만이 전부는 아니라는 걸 알게 됐어요.
text_zh: 我刚入行的时候比较年轻，总觉得产品就是一切。你要是做的产品特别酷，增长肯定没问题。要是做个没人关心的产品或者没人在意的业务线，那增长肯定会慢一些。但后来接触了越来越多厉害的产品经理，看他们怎么做事，我才发现光是做酷炫的产品并不是全部。
text_es: Cuando era más joven y estaba empezando, pensaba que todo se trataba del producto. Si tienes un producto realmente genial en el que trabajar, tu crecimiento está garantizado. Y si tienes un producto que a nadie le importa o un área que a nadie le interesa, entonces tu crecimiento va a ser más lento. Pero conforme empecé a ver a más y más product managers en acción, me di cuenta de que trabajar en un área de producto genial no es lo único que importa.

text: I created a career growth framework for product managers, which comprises of three things, and I call it three W's. So what you produce, what you bring to the table, and what's your operating model? The really strong product managers are good at usually two of the three things. The ones who rise and when they are rising, they are performing well on all the three access.
speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
context: After observing that product success doesn't guarantee career growth, Vikrama created his framework to explain what actually drives PM career advancement. The three W's framework identifies the core areas where product managers need to excel: outputs/deliverables, their unique contributions and skills, and how they collaborate with others. He notes that good PMs typically excel in two areas, but those experiencing rapid career growth perform well across all three dimensions.
text_ko: 저는 프로덕트 매니저(product managers)를 위한 경력 성장 프레임워크(career growth framework)를 만들었어요. 세 가지 요소로 구성돼 있어서 저는 이를 '세 가지 W(three W's)'라고 부릅니다. 즉, 무엇을 만들어 내는지(what you produce), 어떤 가치를 제공하는지(what you bring to the table), 그리고 어떤 식으로 일하는지, 다시 말해 운영 모델(operating model)은 어떤지요. 진짜 강한 프로덕트 매니저들은 보통 이 세 가지 중 두 가지에 강해요. 반면에 실제로 성장하거나 승진하는 사람들은 세 가지 모두에서 잘해요.
text_zh: 我为产品经理做了一个职业发展框架，主要包括三个方面，我叫它"三个W"。就是你能产出什么，你能带来什么价值，还有你的工作方式是怎样的。真正厉害的产品经理通常在这三个方面能做好其中两个。而那些往上升的，正在上升期的产品经理，这三个维度他们都表现得很不错。
text_es: Creé un marco de desarrollo profesional para product managers que tiene tres componentes, y lo llamo "las tres W" (three W's). O sea: qué produces, qué aportas al equipo, y cuál es tu modelo operativo. Los product managers realmente sólidos por lo general dominan dos de estas tres áreas. Los que ascienden y están en pleno crecimiento son los que rinden bien en las tres dimensiones.

text: The mistake that I see a lot of product managers make is they start operating in either output or outcomes. And when you are transitioning to outcomes, it's very important that you continue to still hone your craft on outputs. For instance, do you just give up on the go-to-market strategy or do you start making product nodes which are then picked up by marketing people and are able to be used to create that go-to-market strategy?
speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
context: Vikrama is explaining the first W of his framework - 'what you produce' - which progresses from outputs to outcomes to strategic direction. He warns against a common pitfall where PMs abandon execution skills as they advance in their careers. Even senior PMs should maintain their ability to create detailed, actionable deliverables rather than only focusing on high-level strategy and goals.
text_ko: 제가 자주 보는 실수는 많은 프로덕트 매니저들이 일을 아웃풋(output)이나 아웃컴(outcome) 중 한쪽에만 치우쳐서 시작한다는 거예요. 아웃컴(outcome)으로 전환할 때에도 아웃풋(output)에 대한 역량을 계속 갈고닦는 게 정말 중요해요. 예를 들어, 그냥 고투마켓 전략(go-to-market strategy)을 포기해 버리나요, 아니면 마케팅 담당자들이 가져가서 실제로 그 고투마켓 전략을 만드는 데 쓸 수 있는 프로덕트 노드(product nodes)를 만들기 시작하나요?
text_zh: 我发现很多产品经理都会犯一个错误，就是要么只关注产出(output)，要么只关注结果(outcomes)。当你开始向结果导向转型的时候，继续打磨你在产出方面的能力还是很重要的。比如说，你是直接放弃市场推广策略不管了，还是说你会做一些产品要点(product nodes)，然后市场部的人可以拿去用来制定推广策略？
text_es: El error que veo mucho en los product managers es que empiezan a trabajar solo en outputs o solo en outcomes. Y cuando estás haciendo la transición hacia outcomes, es súper importante que sigas puliendo tu técnica en outputs. Por ejemplo, ¿vas a abandonar completamente la estrategia de go-to-market o empiezas a crear product nodes que después el equipo de marketing pueda usar para armar esa estrategia de go-to-market?

text: You must have that impact through the artifacts that you work on. For a lot of product managers, when I ask, 'Hey, I was working on this very impactful area. I'm not able to have the impact on my career, what is missing?' And when I go and ask, 'Can you show me your last PRD? Can you show me the last product note that you sent? Can you show me the product strategy doc that you have or collaborated on? Can you show me the brief that you sent to the design team on the problems and the ranking of those problems?' Usually, you'll find something or the other missing.
speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
context: Lenny asks about the second W - 'what you bring to the table.' Vikrama explains this means demonstrating your unique impact through tangible work products and documents. When PMs struggle with career growth despite working on successful products, he investigates their actual deliverables like PRDs, strategy docs, and design briefs. Often these artifacts are missing or poor quality, which prevents them from showing their individual contribution to the product's success.
text_ko: 여러분이 만든 산출물(artifacts)을 통해 그 영향력을 보여줘야 해요. 많은 프로덕트 매니저(product managers)들에게 제가 "저는 굉장히 영향력 있는 일을 했는데 그게 경력으로 이어지지 않아요. 뭐가 부족한가요?"라고 물어보면, 제가 "마지막 제품 요구사항 문서(PRD)를 보여줄 수 있어요? 마지막으로 보낸 제품 노트(product note)는요? 직접 작성했거나 함께 작업한 제품 전략 문서(product strategy doc)는요? 디자인팀에 보낸 문제와 그 우선순위를 정리한 브리프(brief)는요?"라고 물어보곤 해요. 보통 뭔가 하나쯤은 빠져 있더라고요.
text_zh: 你必须通过你做的这些具体产出来体现影响力。很多产品经理跟我说，"我在做一个很有影响力的项目，但对我职业发展没什么帮助，到底缺了什么？" 然后我就问他们，"你能给我看看你最近的PRD吗？你发的产品总结能看一下吗？你写的或者参与的产品策略文档在哪里？你给设计团队的需求说明，包括问题优先级排序，能给我看看吗？" 通常情况下，你总会发现这里面缺了点什么。
text_es: Tienes que lograr ese impacto a través de los entregables en los que trabajas. Con muchos product managers, cuando les pregunto: "Oye, estaba trabajando en un área muy impactante, pero no logro tener el impacto que quiero en mi carrera, ¿qué me está faltando?" Y cuando voy y les digo: "¿Me puedes enseñar tu último PRD? ¿Me puedes mostrar la última nota de producto que mandaste? ¿Me puedes enseñar el documento de estrategia de producto que tienes o en el que colaboraste? ¿Me puedes mostrar el brief que le mandaste al equipo de diseño sobre los problemas y la priorización de esos problemas?" Por lo general, vas a encontrar que algo les está faltando.

text: There are three tenets that I define in working well as a product manager with others. Number one is raise difficult issues without being difficult to work with. Bring out important topics without drawing importance to yourself. And finally, you are in charge of getting the decisions made and not making all the decisions yourself.
speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
context: Vikrama is describing the third W - 'your operating model' - which focuses on how PMs collaborate with stakeholders. Due to the 'mini CEO' mythology around product management, many PMs struggle with interpersonal dynamics. He provides three core principles for effective collaboration that help PMs avoid common pitfalls like being seen as difficult or self-important while still driving progress and decision-making.
vocabulary_highlights: in charge of getting the decisions made
text_ko: 다른 사람들과 잘 협업하는 제품 관리자(product manager)가 되기 위해 제가 정한 세 가지 원칙이 있어요. 첫째, 함께 일하기 어렵게 굴지 않으면서도 어려운 이슈는 제기해요. 둘째, 자신을 내세우지 않으면서도 중요한 사안은 꺼내요. 마지막으로, 결정을 내리게 하는 책임은 본인이 지되 모든 결정을 혼자 내리지는 않아요.
text_zh: 我觉得做好产品经理，跟别人配合好，有三个要点。第一个就是该提的难题必须提，但别让人觉得你这个人很难搞。第二个是要把重要的事情摆到台面上来讨论，但不要老想着突出自己。最后一个，你的职责是推动大家把决策做出来，而不是什么决定都你一个人说了算。
text_es: Hay tres principios que defino para trabajar bien como product manager con otros equipos. Primero, saca a la luz los temas complicados sin ser difícil de tratar. Pon sobre la mesa los asuntos importantes sin hacerte el protagonista. Y por último, tu trabajo es lograr que se tomen las decisiones, no tomarlas todas tú solo.

text: The first thing is whether you are focusing on things you control or whether you're focusing on things that are beyond your control. Second, what's your relationship with change? And third is how you see yourself. The third is very, very powerful and we'll talk about that as well.
speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
context: Lenny asks what most impedes people's career growth and what causes PMs to shoot themselves in the foot. Vikrama identifies three critical mindset shifts that can either accelerate or hinder career advancement. He emphasizes that while growth frameworks and rubrics are helpful, these underlying mental patterns often determine whether someone actually progresses in their career, with self-perception being particularly influential.
text_ko: 첫째는 여러분이 통제할 수 있는 것에 집중하고 있는지, 통제할 수 없는 것에 신경 쓰고 있는지예요. 둘째는 변화와 어떤 관계를 맺고 있는지예요. 셋째는 자신을 어떻게 바라보는지예요. 이 셋째가 정말, 정말 강력해요. 그 부분도 이야기해볼게요.
text_zh: 第一点就是，你到底是把精力放在自己能掌控的事情上，还是老想着那些你根本管不了的事儿。第二点，你怎么看待变化这件事？第三点是你怎么看自己。这第三点特别关键，咱们待会儿也会聊到。
text_es: Lo primero es si te estás enfocando en las cosas que puedes controlar o si te estás enfocando en cosas que están fuera de tu control. Lo segundo, ¿cuál es tu relación con el cambio? Y lo tercero es cómo te ves a ti mismo. Este tercer punto es súper poderoso y también vamos a hablar de eso.

text: I see a lot of product managers, that's included me at some stage, doing these things, people will come back and say, 'Oh, I am a very high agency PM' or, 'I'm a very collaborative PM.' Earlier on, I used to think that okay, I need to give this kind of work to these product managers. But then I started understanding these things are not just signaling, they are also anti-signaling. They are like, 'Oh, I'm high agency. So it's sometimes okay if I'm little brash, if I cut corners somewhere, if I sometimes come across as a little rude to some people' and so on, right?
speaker: Vikrama Dhiman
context: Vikrama is explaining the third career impediment - 'how you see yourself.' He describes how PMs often adopt limiting self-narratives that become career obstacles. When PMs label themselves with specific traits like being 'high agency' or 'collaborative,' these labels can inadvertently excuse problematic behaviors. These self-stories become anti-signaling - while meant to highlight strengths, they actually justify weaknesses and prevent growth.
text_ko: 많은 프로덕트 매니저(product managers, PM)들이—저도 한때 그랬지만—이런 식으로 행동하는 걸 자주 봐요. 사람들은 "나는 되게 하이 에이전시(high agency)인 PM이에요" 혹은 "나는 협업형(collaborative) PM이에요"라고 말하죠. 초반에는 "아, 이런 종류의 일은 이런 타입의 PM들에게 맡겨야겠다"라고 생각했어요. 그런데 나중에 보니 이게 단순한 시그널링(signaling)만이 아니라 안티-시그널링(anti-signaling)이기도 하다는 걸 알게 됐어요. 즉 "내가 하이 에이전시니까"라며 가끔 거칠게 굴거나, 어딘가를 대충 넘어가거나, 어떤 사람들한테는 좀 무례하게 보여도 괜찮다고 스스로 정당화하는 면이 있다는 거예요.
text_zh: 我发现很多产品经理，包括我自己以前也是这样，老是爱给自己贴标签，会说"哎呀我是那种很有主动性(high agency)的PM"，或者"我是很善于合作(collaborative)的PM"。一开始我还真信了，觉得好啊，那就把这种活儿给这些产品经理做。但后来我才明白，这些话不光是在给自己加分，其实也在暴露问题。就像那些说自己很有主动性的，潜台词可能是"我很有主动性嘛，所以有时候态度冲一点也没事儿，偷个懒走个捷径也行，对人粗鲁一点也能理解"，你懂我意思吧？
text_es: He visto a muchos product managers, yo incluido en algún momento, haciendo estas cosas. La gente viene y te dice: "Ay, es que soy un PM muy proactivo" o "Soy un PM muy colaborativo". Antes yo pensaba que bueno, necesito darle este tipo de trabajo a estos product managers. Pero después empecé a entender que estas cosas no son solo señales, también son anti-señales. Es como decir: "Soy muy proactivo, entonces a veces está bien si soy un poco brusco, si tomo atajos por aquí y por allá, si a veces me ven medio grosero con algunas personas", ¿no?
